thread.title: Northern Powerhouse minister Jake Berry says Government will keep East Coast line running

author: Sean Seddon
title: Northern Powerhouse minister Jake Berry says Government will keep East Coast line running
text:

With the East Coast Main Line franchise facing imminent collapse, the Northern Powerhouse minister has promised the Government will “keep trains running”. 
Speaking on a visit to Northumberland , Jake Berry MP addressed the ongoing rail crisis and said the Government were determined to boost transport infrastructure in the North, including fixing the A1. 
Transport secretary Chris Grayling has admitted the current Stagecoach-Virgin deal can only stay afloat “for a matter of a very small number of months and no more”. Transport Secretary Chris Grayling (Image: PA) 
He also indicated the Government would be willing to step in and run the service in the short term until structural reforms and a new operator can be put in place. 
Mr Berry said ensuring customers aren’t effected by the third private sector collapse of the franchise since 2007 is essential. 
He said: “It’s absolutely crucial there is no interruption to services and the priority of this Government is to keep trains running. 
“The Department for Transport is working on a plan to deliver better value for money for the taxpayers. 
“We’re looking for a long term solution to make sure we get the right deal and I’m confident that this Government will do that.” 
Mr Berry, who was born in Liverpool and has been Northern Powerhouse minister since June 2017, said Transport for the North could be a game-changer for the region. Northern Powerhouse minister Jake Berry visiting St Aiden's winery on Holy Island, Northumberland (Image: Newcastle Chronicle) 
The transport authority will assume a more powerful statutory footing in April and set out a 30-year plan to boost growth in the region by investing in transport infrastructure last month. 
Mr Berry said it will allow the region to address long-running problems which have been overlooked by previous administrations, such as dualing the A1. 
Plans to close a four-mile stretch of the road in March to allow for resurfacing work have solicited opposition from businesses this week. Read More North East Brexit disaster? Northern Powerhouse minister Jake Berry MP dismisses chilling report 
He said: “Anybody who has lived here their whole lives knows that transport is a challenge. 
“This Government is putting in more money into Northern transport investment than any before and that has to continue. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now 
“We’re fully behind Transport for the North which means London no longer gets to say what’s good for us and I’d encourage everyone to engage and support that process. 
“It will ensure local priorities are addressed and the A1 will be in there, although it’s too early to say what outcomes will emerge at the moment. 
“But it’s complex - we’ve seen protests this weeks over closing that road to allow for improvements. Read More Private or public? North's transport tsar on why the East Coast Main Line debate misses the point 
“That shows that, while the work needs to be done, you need to get the planning right.” 
Speaking to ChronicleLive last week, TfN’s director of strategy Jonathan Spruce called on the government to implement wholesale reform of the East Coast franchise to prevent turbulence in the future. Like us on Facebook
